On the bright side, the story is very simple and got no politics and boring sequences in it - on the down side, it is one of the most recycled ideas you've seen in cinema - and you won't have the chance to see it on the big screen, because is streamed into Netflix almost right away.It has Snyder's iconic and unstoppable or uncontrolled slow-MO's scenes, it has a lot of pathos in it, mainly from the main protagonist character that is played in an exaggerated way for almost most of her part. She is a mediocre actress and not build to lead this scale of a movie. Wherever Djimon Hounsou is participating, you know that it is going to be not that good. You can say it also on most of Charlie Hunnam's movies and to say the truth also on last years performences of Cary Elwes and even Anthony Hopkins. It has a lot of small-scale stars that get small and unrememberable performances, but there is one you will not be able to forget and it is the new baddy of Hollywood - Ed Skrein performance is marvelous.The concept is familiar, the visual side is very rich and colorful, the script is a minor-minor part of the movie and the aspiration is high, very high even... Snyder shoots to capture a new fan base audience for his market and Netflix is the correct platform for it. Not sure his followers will follow, but when you don't have anything else to see and you don't want an actual mini-Series: make your own from Snyder's movie.

title: Rebel Moon: A Disappointment Wrapped in Slow-Mo
text: Rebel Moon: A Disappointment Wrapped in Slow-MoI dove into Rebel Moon with high hopes, but unfortunately, it fell short on nearly every front. The biggest letdown was the dialogue. It felt like someone skimmed a thesaurus of generic action movie phrases and strung them together with minimal effort. Imagine a ten-year-old tasked with writing a cool movie script - that's the vibe I got.Then there's the runtime. Two hours should be enough to tell a compelling story, but Rebel Moon felt stretched thin. Large chunks of the film were filler, dragging the pace and leaving me checking my watch. It felt like they were desperately trying to justify the hefty budget.Now, let's talk about the action. It was, in a word, atrocious. The choreography was clunky and lacked any real impact. The lead actress, bless her heart, clearly wasn't comfortable with the fight sequences. The solution? Slow-motion everything! Every punch, every kick, every dodge was stretched and distorted, turning potentially exciting moments into snooze-fests. It felt like a desperate attempt to mask the lack of skill and choreography.John Wick, for example, sets the gold standard for action films. Keanu Reeves' dedication to mastering fight choreography shines through in every scene. There's a rawness and intensity to the action that Rebel Moon simply couldn't capture. Here, it felt like they were relying on slow-motion to create a sense of coolness that just wasn't there.The film also stumbled with its attempts at character development. We're supposed to believe that a few generic motivational lines can completely change someone's life path and inspire them to join a rebellion. It felt unearned and lazy. Where was the emotional depth? Where were the moments that made us truly care about these characters and their fight?Rebel Moon had the potential to be an epic sci-fi adventure. It had a decent premise, some cool visuals, and a talented cast (who deserved better material). But in the end, it was a shallow spectacle with forgettable characters, nonsensical dialogue, and action sequences that felt more like parodies than genuine thrills.If you're looking for a sci-fi film that delivers on all fronts, you'll want to steer clear of Rebel Moon.

title: Seen this movie too many times
text: I finally saw it last night, and I can safely say it was a much better movie than "Jupiter Ascending". So was it good, it was because there was no 'forced messaging' was it bad, no, there are far worse crap out there (I am looking at you sequal trillogy) The biggest problem is, there was ZERO originality in any thing in this show. You can CLEARLY see all the Star Wars characters and zero effort was made to divulge the plot lines, they just changed the names and costumes. The plot is stolen right out of Bugs Life/7 Samuri/Magnificent 7 etc. The problem is, they would have to be all superhuman to pull this off. It would be like if Obiwon and Anakin singlehandedly took down the Seperatists.Now lets talk about the costumes. They were horrible and took me out of the immersion. It felt more like I was watching a documentary on the British occupation of Ireland than a science fiction. The native clothing was too familiar even Firefly managed to do better on a limited budget and they are actual humans whose history is closer to ours than in Rebel Moon. However far in the future this is from humanity (or a long long time ago) they dressed like 19th century Irish. The imperial uniforms were better but also very reminiscent of 20th century Huns.I don't mind the buildings and structures looking familiar because let's be honest, a good design is a good design anywhere you live. The only difference is style, and they probably should have put some effort into making the buildings 'style' more alien and less Viking settlement.Again it wasn't horrible but I predicted virtually everything that happened, there were no surprises (AT ALL) so it was like playing a game when you know all the answers or playing a video game on Godmode. It was just boring.

title: When you order star wars from wish!
text: Such a disappointing film from all aspects. Plot, acting, special effects and editing.It's a very hard watch and struggle to see why Netflix picked this up. Did they think this was going to be the next star wars franchise and jumped on it or did they grab it just to stop anyone else getting it. The story is all over the place and you can't help play the game of match the characters with the star wars cast.You get the farm boy/girl, the smuggler, the warrior, the swordsman, the evil dictator, even a cp30 type droid.At over 2 hours it really feels a long drawn out movie and there's a part 2 coming..... Why?...

title: 6/10 enjoyable
text: In an age of cinema where original ideas are often overlooked in place of sequels, remakes, adaptations from books and games. This movie feels no different. This movie has a feel as its from a book series, with an established lore and characters we all should know and love....... but it's not. I kept finding myself watching this and seeing the way they would introduce a new character and I would get this feeling like "awe thats so-n-so" but remember I had no idea lol. I felt left out, dying to know more.As the story goes, I found it watchable. Yes it's a "star wars" knock off, but those in the know knew this was coming. Felt every Mandaolrian/Rogue One.Cinematography wise the movie could have been 40 minutes shorter without Zach's "spartan 300" slow motion action sequence in almost every scene. I felt it slowed the pacing down, ejecting me from caring about what was playing out.Another thing I felt was every distracting, and I am not sure if it was my ratio aspect or the movie but, while the characters up front and present where clear the background and around the center of the screen was blurry. More so then normal, as if it was an effort to exaggerate this effect.

title: Zack Snyder's blatant space adventure that plays like Star Wars fan fiction
text: I remember the moment I connected to Zack Snyder's aesthetic. It was a slow-motion shot from Batman v Superman: Dawn of Justice of a flood survivor reaching her hand desperately to Superman, cape billowing in the sky.Initially, I thought, is it unnecessary to hold a visual for that long? Wouldn't it be more economical to have a montage of Superman saving people from the flood instead, like how Christopher Nolan might do in his more left-brained approach?Then, it hit me that Zack Snyder's artistic intention is akin to a still painting, or a comic book splash page, and the audience is meant to bask in the prolonged moment and imagine the story behind the image, filling in what happened before and after.I've since accepted Zack Snyder's visual storytelling style and his alternative way of thinking, even its flaws, and have retroactively enjoyed his films on a whole new level. Zack Snyder's Justice League is his best work to date.Snyder's latest film released on Netflix, Rebel Moon, is an uninspired space adventure that indulges in long stretches of world-building and showcases its characters like a collection of action figures, before getting the audience to care about them.Rebel Moon, pitched as "Seven Samurai set in the Star Wars universe'", originated as a story treatment Zack Snyder wrote in film school and was unsuccessfully pitched to Lucasfilm as a Star Wars movie. Following up on his partnership with Netflix after 2021's Army of the Dead, the story pitch has been reworked and released as an epic two-parter.The film's biggest sin lies in its unoriginality. The script does little to repackage or find alternative original moments of its own. It feels like stepping into Zack Snyder's subconscious and seeing everything he's a fan of all clumped together.Its cinematic influences are so blatant that film fans will immediately spot which movies the script is pulling from. There are droids, lightsabers, the Mos Eisley Cantina, its own version of Han Solo, and a familiar sequence from the first Avatar.As the screenwriter, Zack Snyder also has a perplexing understanding of "show, don't tell". He can compose fantastic breathtaking visuals but still chooses to give exposition through words in the most boring way possible.Shockingly, every character is introduced exactly the same. As the two farmers set off to recruit its ensemble of warriors across the galaxy, the routine quickly becomes repetitive.Enter character. The character displays fighting ability and their backstory is verbally told. The character says yes. The recruiters move to recruit the next warrior on another planet. Repeat.Snyder's trademark slow-motion shots didn't work as there was no emotional attachment to any of these characters or any substance behind the story for the audience to truly bask in. And at times, I was eagerly waiting for the next shot.Rebel Moon re-highlights the lesson of Sucker Punch: Zack Snyder works better when he's working with a screenwriter, namely to do the plotting and keep him from his worst tendencies.Ironically, or unironically depending on how you look at it, the film plays out exactly like what it sounds like on paper: Star Wars fan fiction. It truly can be enjoyed as the more mature and violent version of Star Wars.That's how I ended up enjoying Rebel Moon. It's gotten up to 63 million views on Netflix within ten days of its release, so I cannot be alone. Certainly, there must be lots of people enjoying it in this way as well.George Lucas' idea behind manufacturing toys was to allow fans to tell their own stories in the Star Wars universe. Admittedly, I wrote Star Wars fan fiction as a 12-year-old in a Creative Writing class, which were John Woo movies set in the Star Wars universe.Rebel Moon would have certainly satisfied my 12-year-old self. Donna Bae, Snyder's version of a Jedi, wielding dual red laser swords battling Jenna Malone as a villainous arachnid cybernetic alien is truly metal.All that said, can I say Rebel Moon is great and everybody should see it? No.Did I enjoy it? Yes, I found enough pieces to enjoy it for what it was, though I still cannot defend it.Will I watch Part 2? Yes, but only as more Star Wars fan fiction.

title: Action-packed and Really Good
text: I am starting to think from the low reviews that people did not watch the same movie I watched. I thoroughly enjoyed this movie and cannot wait until its next chapter in April. To me, it was another stellar Zack Snyder movie.The movie contains strong action-scenes, unabashed violence, a solid storyline and backstory, an underdog trope, really good acting, a psychologically (and sometimes physiologically) torned protagonist, and an effective supporting cast. Cinematically, the scenes of the different planets were varied and intriguing. Sofia Boutella was the perfect choice for the lead role... she possesses such confidence, beauty, mysteriousness, femininity, and strength all at the same time. I am not quite sure how Zack got all of these qualities in one actor... but Sofia hit them on the nail all at the same time.Again, I respect everyone else's view... I simply found this movie a treat to watch and would recommend it for any Zack Snyder, sci-fi, galactic war, underdog-theme, action-seeking, and/or Sofia Boutella fan.

title: Some decent SciFi here
text: Don't understand all the hateful comments here.Seems like the audience lost the sense for SciFi. C'mon, if you can't handle such kind of SciFi better stay with Marvel.Was it the best movie ever? No.Was it a bad movie? No.Did it deserve all of the hatred? Definitely not!The movie (1st part so far) has a solid (but forseeable) story, good acting and incredible images/sceneries. The villain offered an amazing performance - you know from the first second, he's not a nice guy - and later on you really start to hate him without any problems.Personally, I can't wait for the next part being aired in April.

title: New levels of bad
text: The short version of my review is: Fantastic cast wasted on a complete piece of garbage.If Snyder EVER has an original thought, the poor thing is absolutely 1000% certain to DIE OF LONELINESS! I felt like I might go MAD if I tried to keep straight where he lifted what bit from. Yes, this happens in other movies, of course it does-- but in those other movies, there's enough GOOD to distract me from that. Here? Oh, hell, no!The man's OBSESSION with ultra-slow motion was another problem, and the movie could have been several minuntes shorter if he'd used ORDINARY slow motion, which would have actually worked better.It's garbage, seriously. The whole meme thing of "Star Wars with blackjack and hookers" is in no way wrong. If anything, I think that it's understated. I'm CERTAIN that it will be understated when the R-rated version gets released later this year.Save some brain cells. Avoid it like the plague.

title: Rebel Moon hasn't met a sci-fi idea it doesn't like...and I hate that I enjoyed it anyway
text:
Rebel Moon - Part One: A Child of Fire angers me. I always make an effort to avoid anything I plan to review (as best I can in this age of social media shenanigans), but Zack Snyder has this strange ability to whip online pundits into a frenzy. So, my timelines across the board flooded with unwavering loyalty and gleeful hate, leaving me frankly terrified to step into Netflix's new space opera epic.That's not what angers me, though. No, what angers me is, as much as A Child of Fire gets right, it's a smorgasbord of plots done better...and I still had a damn good time.Rebel Moon - Part One: A Child of Fire is a frustrating experience that hasn't met a sci-fi or fantasy story it doesn't like. It's worn, overly reliant on tropes, and far too indulgent in layering slow-motion scenes on top of slow-motion scenes...
...and I still absolutely loved it. Visually stunning and satisfyingly punchy, Part One of Snyder's new franchise is a fun watch and potentially potent foundation that just might reach the cult status it so desperately wants to skip to.

title: Monotone! Flat! Emotionless.
text: "Rebel Moon falls short for me, lacking the emotional depth that could truly captivate. The storytelling feels lackluster, like a tale narrated without passion, leaving the overall experience somewhat dull. The film's narrative structure appears scattered, lacking a clear path and coherence, diminishing its overall impact. However, within these drawbacks, I glimpse a potential for greatness, indicating that with thoughtful adjustments, Rebel Moon could ascend to the epic heights it initially promised. Strengthening character connections and refining the plot might just transform this cinematic venture into the captivating journey it has the potential to be, at least from my perspective."

title: Just bad!
text:
They must have used up all the cliches in the book.If you have never seen a movie before in your life, you are going to really like this one. Otherwise....
Why would a future alien society that has lasers and space travel work the fields by hand? Or pray to "old gods" or act like vikings?The bad army ressembles the nazis in an absolutely unnecessary way and of course the "main soldiers" don't wear helmets because you need to recognize them on the battlefield.Action and storyline is easy to foresee and, except shootings, all fights are turn based. As in, all the bad guy wait for their turn to take a shot at the good guy.And to top it all out, accents make absolutely no sense.

title: I liked it
text:
Like others, not sure why people are hating on this so much. It's a decent film, decent story line and, other than the weird / bad Irish accent that wasn't required on one of the lead characters, the acting was good.Yes, there were sections that reminded me of Star Wars, lord of the rings, Harry Potter, Star Trek and Game of Thrones but it was a decent plot and if they've made part 2 well I think it'll all Come together nicely. Personally I'm
Looking forward to watching part 2 and I would let these negative reviews put me off watching it.Advice - watch it and make your own mind up and don't let snobs ruin it for you!

title: So empty...
text: What happening to story telling as a skill. This is terrible, I literally don't care for not even one of characters. The only who I can sympatyze with the most is Noble, the evil dude. He has much more layers and is presented more in detail than any other character. I feel this is the problem with 90% of the movies today. People think that SGI and action can compromise the lack of story, characters and love for the film, but they really can't and that's why we are seeing more and more of these terrible movies. I wasn't moved by one scene in a movie, the main character isn't presented as it should, the other are there obviously just to be there and the worst thing is the literally have no impact in the movie.... I don't know, it just very bad, shame on you Zack.

title: Definitely not new, but at least watchable
text: Had no expectations while going into this and was pleasantly surprised by the visuals. The cast of well known actors also works to draw you in. I appreciate that at least the costumes and the cgi do not look cheap. If you are looking for an original story or at least some original worldbuilding this is not for you. If you are just looking for some nice visuals, decent dialogue and a plot that will not challenge you this is worth your time. We even laughed at some point about the typology of each character as well as the fact that they seem to have been auditioning for their part of the misfit team. Also, it is good to know that the tone is highly serious ans tragic and that there is no comedic character and no humour.

title: Frankenstine plot, Korra from Avatar.
text: The plot id just someone took plot points from other well known movies so it makes no sense. You have the "protect the farmers" plot from Magnificent 7. Which doesnt make any sense because why do you have farmers when you have androids? In Star Wars which this is a rip off, Luke Owen and Bru used the farm droids. They didnt pull a plow. And why is it always the girls that beat up everyone? Im so tired of this. As a woman, Id like to see some heroic men. I dont want to see the rufff butch heroine any more. I mean it was fun at first because they weren't in 100% of films. Im suspicious of the score. It cant be this hi. Why would anyone like this?

title: Just a lover of SF and acting and story good
text: Nice story and good actors (+ for Gunner). Story nice and a warning to all that is happening in the world right now. Freedom is a precious thing. If we think about this beyond this world and planet and we go on making the same mistakes this is a story that learns us a lot. Forget the story and enjoy the future imagination of worlds and inhabitants trying to live and survive this is a great movie. We have two choices: 1. Continue with what we are doing and this film will be reality 2. Stop wars and work together and be one. This shows what we think will happen when we go to outer space. If you like SF you will enjoy this film.

title: Mehhh..
text: After being wowed by Zack Snyder's bold directorial vision in visual spectacles like 300 and Man of Steel, Rebel Moon feels like a generic letdown - hardly worthy of his stylized filmmaking might.We've seen the core premise play out in countless fantasy tales - lethal despot dominating hapless settlements until one victimturned-renegade decides enough is enough. Rebel Moon brings nothing narratively fresh to this archetype. It's the classically engineered, emotionally manipulative core designed to easily hook viewers rather than challenge or subvert their expectations.Our protagonist heroine follows all the tropes of gathering a ragtag group of resistance fighters we know will obviously band with her based on overly convenient writing. Oh she's searching for specific skilled allies across the galaxy? What fortune they all happen to reside within quick succession in plot-necessitated locales!The story arcs and character purpose feels pre-ordained to serve shoehorned themes of unity and overcoming rather than developing meaningful stakes or reveals that shock or intrigue.Sure, Rebel Moon checks off the fantasy action adventure boxes, but with hardly any innovation or directorial panache that made Snyder's best works iconic. Unless craving a processed, binge-able intergalactic quest, I'd recommend numerous deeper genre films instead of this been-there-seen-that freshman storyline without heart. Snyder has lost his rebel spirit churning uninspired content now backed by Hollywood casino financing.

title: unbelievable
text: A 80 pound girl boss blocks and kills 7 powerful yet accommodating stuntmen with her wee, spindly arms, only to then tell the large group of dopey male onlookers that it's time to fight. Why does every bloody action film have to have a female hero at the center of it. How many times does Hollywood have to lose money before the penny drops. Southpark nailed it." We don't understand, we keep making the same movie over and over" People aren't sick of action and superhero movies, just sick of the same one over and over again. A strong unbeatable women who just is strong and unbeatable for no good reason.

title: I enjoyed this for what it is a Zach Snyder movie what are you expecting?
text: First off it's common knowledge the script was dropped off at Disney for a Star wars movie. But they wasn't interested they are more interested spending the entire budget here of rebel moon on she hulk or marvels or eternals for instance. It's typical Zach Snyder over kill on slow mo and action little on expedition. I was thoroughly entertained watching this, but you do need a 4k TV with surround sound to really appreciate what you're watching. It's not meant to smart or interlectal. It's meant to be eye candy and entertaining this is where it works wonders this film is ridiculously entertaining but you have to switch off the grey matter and enjoy it for what it is a space opera with little logic. This film is here to enjoy and I am looking forward to the next part. I hope there is some more fleshing out of the world with a definite ending.

title: A solid opener for a new franchise inspired by a classic
text: Rebel Moon is loosely inspired by Akira Kurosawa's Seven Samurai. In which a poor farmer enlists the help of a veteran samurai to protect their village from bandits who intend to steal their barley. The veteran gathers six men who teach the farmers how to fight...does that ring a bell?It will be a tragedy to watch Rebel Moon without first seeing or knowing Seven Samurai. Do not take the bad reviews seriously, most were expecting a Star Wars spin off. Rebel Moon is not! At worst, the source material for this new sci fi franchise is Dune not Star Wars.I can't wait for the Directors Cut and the sequel. It is bound to be a solid opener to a new franchise indeed.

title: So bad it's kinda good
text: Movie actually starts with a giant phallus coming through what can only be described as what a giant phallus is meant to go through. And that's about as subtle as it's going to get. Sci Fi tropes? You betcha. Got your technologically advanced bad guys versus the simple rural folk. Charming space pirate is he a good guy or a bad guy? Robot with a soul. Fantastic space beasts. Big CGI battle at the end. Dune like power squabble and race of master soldiers. There's even a character with mythical abilities weilding what might as well be light sabers. The only thing thinner than the plot and character development appears to be the CGI budget. But, it somehow works when the stars do what stars do best, make you want to watch them. The lead actors charismatic performance, both the good guys and bad guys, pulls it all together into a great big craptastastic fun to watch mess.

title: Really Bad
text: Was expecting the movie to be good after watching the trailer. The movie is so bad that I couldn't watch it in one sitting. Too much slo mo, literally every fight scene has slo mo. Story is basic, bad acting and directing. The storyline seems too forced. No real motivation or reasons for the side characters to do what they did! The side characters are really bad. It was supposed to be a world building movie but there were too many things mashed up together. And yes, its too much like star wars, although i tried very hard to keep the comparisons out of my head while watching the movie but i just couldn't.

title: You do know this was supposed to be a Star Wars right?
text: It really boggles my mind the lack of research so called movie buffs put unto their love of film. Lucasfilm cut Zack Snyder's Star Wars film, amongst others, when their sequel trilogy fell flat amongst that fan base, and they refocused their efforts into their Disney+ series. So Zack took it upon himself to rework a Star Wars script that he wrote and made it into an original script. Yes it birriws heavily from Star Wars because it was supposed to be a Star Wars movie. Is it a great film of course not, but it isn't terrible either. Most of actors played their roles well. Visually it's as grim as the story is itself and that works for me.

title: Waste of time
text: What a boring and derivative film. Why make something like this at all?!Throughout the film, I had the impression that every scene was copied from a film I knew from the cinema. With every action I knew what was going to happen next. I wonder what the world sees in the person of the director, but every film is a bigger nothing.It's fortunate that it's streaming and not cinema, because at least you could cook dinner and write back to your friends in the meantime.That I seem to have lost something through these extra activities! On the contrary, I gained a sense of a little less lost time.Never again.

title: Don't get the bad reviews
text: Is it like Stars Wars ... Yes.Is it like Dune ... Yes.Is it like Antz ... Yes.Are all the above good shows ... Yes.Is it actually those GOOD shows ... No.Did I enjoy watching it ... Yes !!!Can Rebel Moon not be just judged on it own merits. There is a good story line, there is excellent visual effects. The cast is fantastic and their acting on the show is up to a high standard.As I write this I am look forward to the next installment. However like similar movies that get review bombed I hope it doesn't face the same fate. Where we are robbed of more movies because of a viral gripe over mediocre reasons.

title: Waiting for part 2
text: There are many scenes that lead you to believe that this is a rip off of Star Wars (or Dune, which influenced that heavily). Then there are the homages to other movies that at first seem accidental, then intentional. Since this movie stands on its own, it's allowed to do such things, and I think in the end it was appreciated. Yes the action is mostly slow and boring and done before. The movie is entirely too long for how much time it spent on said slow action scenes, yet still rewatchable. The dialogue and story were all over the place, choppy and a flat out mess. The characters are mostly unlikable, but still enjoyable to watch. You're actively exploring them as people and in some cases watching them explore themselves.I'm glad this was made. If I have to watch another franchise movie other than Dune, I'll scream. We don't need more marvel movies or more Star Wars movies, we need movies that take from those, fix their flaws and make them better. This movie is a start. We must support movies like this because it'll get others made. Boycott money grabbing franchises and start watching this.

title: Terrible Screenplay
text:
Well I was waiting for this but when i watched it is so disappointing that it is hard to tolerate Snyder over did slomo like unnecessary slomos there was a part i was thinking why like in the beginning of the movie there is a fight scene and you can feel that at some point why just why actually not only beginning but every fight scene when she run when ducks when she jumps even when she misfires everything even her breathe.It's like its a slomo project with a little bit of movie in it
Acting was okay but story i don't know where it is heading and yes cgi was good but again why that stupid blur effect on literally every frame. I just wanna say this movie doesn't worth time or money.

title: A CLONE BY ANY OTHER NAME...?
text: Zach Snyder is back w/the Star Wars saga he wanted to make in this Netflix original currently streaming. Borrowing whole hog from Akira Kurasawa's Seven Samurai, Snyder has fashioned a tale of a lost scion, played by Sofia Boutella, from a militaristic empire now found on a homey back world toiling away as a farmer's assistant but when Imperial forces find them to replenish their food piles (which they'll do by force), Boutella comes to the rescue of an endangered maiden killing off all the stationed troops. Gathering the village elders together, Boutella formulates a plan to gather warriors to fight the good fight when the shock troops return sending the narrative into familiar (wildly familiar!) territory as Boutella corrals her soldiers to fight on different worlds w/a shady trader, Charlie Hunnam, as her guide & one of her cohorts from the farm planet, Michiel Huisman (who carries an obvious torch for her), tagging along. If you know Kurasawa's magna opus (which I do) or even John Sturges American remake from 1960 or even the Denzel Washington retread he made w/Antonie Fuqua a few years ago then you know where this story is going w/an ending leaving it wide open (in Kurasawa version's this is where the intermission title card comes in) for a follow-up (which is expected in April) but where am I in the critical state of things w/Snyder's take. It was fine for what it was & for those who are of the initiated w/the previous iterations may find it epic, new & enthralling but applying the template w/a sci-fi flavor (hell this was done by Roger Corman w/his Battle Beyond the Stars in 1980) & claiming this is something novel is one thing when a simple remark of taking Kurasawa's fable & giving it a try would've been enough but unfortunately in the press Snyder has gone w/the former explanation which has made him a punching bag for critics unless it's a sly ploy. Who knows but if you want to have a passable time killer running in the background at home, saddled w/o new Star Wars product on any radar, this'll do.

title: Would have rated 6/10 but one point more for for the undeserved negativity it is getting
text: Well it's a familiar world. Though there are a lot of plot holes, one could pick out more, even in the Star Wars trilogy. Also needs to be considered that Disney refused Jack Snyder's offer of making the film in the Star Wars universe.So he went ahead in creating his own universe that is dark and senseless. There are a lot of questions and lot many are left unanswered. Yet it's universe that's worth visiting just to forget the universe we live in.Yes, the film takes you on a cinematic ride. A ride on a grand canvas though arguably riddled with holes. But which you might miss if you just let go of yourself and enjoy the spectacle unfolding in front of your eyes.One thing you won't regret is the action, especially the breathtaking fight sequence executed by Kora, as she saves Sam.The creatures in the movie seem a bit outlandish and a product of imagination gone wild. Yet they do give the viewer some vibes of the the old Star War movies.There are a lot of similarities with Star Wars. Like the character of clueless Gunner which looks similar to the one played by Harrison Ford. Character Kora feels deceptively similar to Jedi, of course without the force. And not forgetting rag tag band of rebels.It's a fast paced movie with a lot of characters thrown in, with little time for character development. May be we might see more in the the next movie.Watch it, enjoy it, who knows there might be a beautiful journey ahead waiting in the sequels. And even if not, it's worth watching as a stand-alone movie.

title: Wow that's bad
text: It says part 1 but I couldn't imagine a reason why anyone would want to watch part 2. I was really looking forward to this movie, I thought it was gonna be fun, seemed like a cool story and I thought I liked the cast. I was wrong. This movie was absolutely awful. The main actor should not be leading a film, she's not good enough to carry any scenes. The most disappointing part of the movie to me though was the action. I expected non stop well choreographed action and instead got some of the worst fight scenes that I can remember. I understand there are enjoyable action movies you can turn your brain off for and they're still fun, this isn't one of them.

title: Don't judge after the bad reviews
text: Oooky so i don't understand why so much bad reviews. So it's a mix of star wars and suicide squad. It's true that the green screen is not as high quality as the Mandalorian, clearly there is no comparison, but still... The alien creatures who show are really well done and ships and the battles are really oky. I must say there was plot twist that left me... say whaaaat. So i definitely did not get bored and i can't wait to see the second part. Basically in the first part you get to know the characters, a little bit of their stories and you have a background of the story. My boyfriend mentioned they tend to overdo it with the slow motion for dramatic effect but i wasn't bothered by it. The main character really does a good job in portraying her story and reason to fight. Definitely deserves more than 5 this movie. Don't compare it with star wars or other classicals, just take it as it is, a sci fi fantasy rebellion maybe in a universe parallel from star wars.

title: the definition of a waste of time and money in cinematography
text: The only reason i gave it 3 stars is because the visuals were quite amazing sometimes, costumes and character concept/design were great. Kudos to the concept art team.Now the bad: the story was straight up boring and full of cliches, the characters were cookie cutter and lacked any development - i really feel bad for the cast of great actors that had nothing to work with - it says something when the most interesting character is Jimmy the robot that appeared in 3% of the movie. The whole story is disjointed and feels like it was written with chat gpt.The lenses choice had me raising eyebrows, i get the reason was to get an unique look but unique doesn't equal good looking and combined with the high contrast look the out of focus background was a distracting mess most of the time.The overuse of slow motion was another thing that greatly ruined the action scenes, just why? Feels like an overenthusiastic kid was allowed to play with special effects when editing.I wonder if Snyder is proud of this movie.

title: A Great Sci-Fi Film
text: I am a big film fan and I get everyone has their own opinions but I don't get how many bad reviews this is getting. I am a Snyder fan and I thought this was a really enjoyable film with a good cast. I'm not saying it was one of the best ever sci-fi films but it was still entertaining. This part was clearly about getting to know the characters and setting the scene I think. I believe there is a lot more to look forward to in the second part where the story will come out more. Ed Skrein was cast really well as the villain again also which I liked. The film did try and copy a bit of Star Wars maybe but so what. Bring on part 2!!!

title: Something you should know about this movie
text: As the title clearly said: (part 1) well, it is that; "half of a 2-part movie", so I don't understand why there are so many ignorant people saying that the movie is bad if "you still have to watch the rest of the movie".Another detail is that many scenes were cut in order to reduce the film at 2 hours and so it was suitable for audiences pg-13.I imagine that later we will be able to see the extended version. I think what is said in the majority of negative reviews has no real basis and the only thing intended here is to attack Snyder.I did enjoy this part 1 and I can't wait to watch part 2!

title: If 'Wish' did Star Wars
text: Rarely I am compelled to review a film, but this film is awful. There have been many movies attempting to emulate Star Wars, this being with this being a terrible tribute.So many plot holes, no character development, forced dialogues with weak monologues, poor acting (not all) , and unnecessary slow mo's .The cinematography is nice, but everything feels forced. So many scenes are unbelievable and unnecessary and and obvious 'copy and paste' from previous versions.I assume the next films will fill in the details, but in reality I don't want to waste Time my time with them.Overhyped but I'm sure Ladbible will make sure it's popular.

title: Not bad at all.
text: Yes some of the concepts are somewhat borrowed, yes the overuse of slow mo gets a little annoying... but it's well acted, well made and overall not worth the low scores. Would recommend to any sci-fi fan.Yes some of the concepts are somewhat borrowed, yes the overuse of slow mo gets a little annoying... but it's well acted, well made and overall not worth the low scores. Would recommend to any sci-fi fan.Yes some of the concepts are somewhat borrowed, yes the overuse of slow mo gets a little annoying... but it's well acted, well made and overall not worth the low scores. Would recommend to any sci-fi fan.

title: A decent 2 hours of a (probably) very good 3 hour movie
text: Rebel Moon part one is by no means a bad movie and it doesn't deserve the level of hate that it has received. The film's biggest problem is that it doesn't spend enough time with each of its characters which robs the climax of the weight and spectacle it was trying for. Fortunately, that problem is very likely to be fixed in the three hour R-rated cut of the film expected to be released in summer of 2024. I can understand wanting two cuts of the movie, but I do not understand the decision to release the inferior version first.With that said, this movie is visually awesome, the characters that we get sufficient time with are great, and the world we are shown is fascinating and intriguing enough to make you want to see more. It's a Zack Snyder Star Wars movie, for better and for worse. In my opinion, it's still better Star Wars than 90% of what Disney has been giving us. Don't listen to critics and haters, watch the movie and decide for yourself because I found myself having a very good time with this one even despite its issues.

title: Disappointing
text: If you told me this movie had been made by ai I would have believed you. There is not a single character that this movie managed to get me to care about, everyone was so cliche, every storyline, every dialogue, every trope has been done before. Sometimes media manages to depend on this formula so that it generated some guaranteed revenue, but it just feels like there's no emotion, originality or creativity to be found in this. It just felt like a mash-up of famous media, like a movie I've watched before a million times.There are so many things you can do with the sci-fi genre, so much space to create any time of story you want, you are working with a literal blank canvas if you so choose to. So it baffles me why you would just make a star wars imitation without any of the things that make star wars actually watchable.I only gave this four stars cause the actors and the visual effects teams deserve better than this, ever tho all the performances felt dry, I choose to attribute it to the script this time around, as it was clearly lacking in every other aspect as well.

title: Boring.
text: I had modest expectations for this film, yet its quality was subpar. The narrative appears to amalgamate elements from both Star Wars and Dune, with an evident instance of dialogue plagiarism from the latter, notably during Admiral Atticus' second execution. It is a very cliche plot line and struggles to find originality.Regrettably, there is little positive commentary to offer; this movie proves unengaging and fails to captivate throughout its duration. My recommendation is to abstain from investing your time in this lackluster production. Rebel Moon proved disappointment offering very little in terms of entertainment or innovation.

I was lucky to see this film at a crew showing, and let me tell you - do NOT listen to the critics take. This movie has a big budget and it shows. The set, actors, the costumes, the fight sequences- all awesome. The story may feel familiar, as we are living in an age where we ourselves can feel as if we're being crushed by a dystopian overlord. Stranger Things gave nods to everything 80s and no one said boo. Zack Snyder gives nods to space throw backs and it's scoffed?! I encourage watch the movie, enjoy it, and then write a good review. Let's damn these critics - they're not our overlords. We are the ones who decide what's a good movie, and what is tired. I promise you, Rebel Moon is a fantastic ride. It's entertainment, and that's what we're here for, right?

title: Yet ANOTHER Snyder Cut is in the works
text: Don't let the rotten tomato scores fool you, Rebel Moon is far from a terrible movie but it's also a ways away from being a perfect one.Rebel Moon has everything you come to expect from a Zack Snyder flick however it feels and legitimately is a movie made specifically for a studio. Snyder has gone on record stating that his agreement with Netflix involved making PG-13 movies AND unfiltered/rated R versions of said movies. The results stemming from this decision are noticeable.Although the diverse group of characters have intriguing backstories, the film doesn't have enough time to fully delve into the formation of the team. You just have to accept these are tough people fighting together because they hate the antagonists for one reason or another.The action is surprisingly tame while simultaneously pushing the boundaries of the PG-13 rating. It's easy to imagine more intense firefights and gory brawls had there not been a "leash" on the filmmakers' vision.Naturally there are a lot of exposition dumps to explain the lore of this new sci-fi world. There's a lot more telling than there was showing when it comes to narrative but all the performances somewhat alleviate this shortcoming. The spectacular visuals and stylized action also makes up for it to a certain extent.Rebel Moon is an enjoyable film with a fair amount of shortcomings. This sci-fi universe is fascinating and has a lot of potential for growth. If you're a fan of Zack Snyder's work or sci-fi in general I'd recommend at least checking it out but I think the better version of this film is unfortunately yet to be released.

title: Remember what happened to Game of thrones?
text: Just like those famous seasons of Game of thrones, which weren't based on books and proved so clearly how important good writing is. You can't just put a lot of sci-fi trope in a golden blender and expect something good coming out of it.Everyone is already commented on the acting, but I like to make another point. It's this inconsistentency with technology advancement. So we've figured out how to fold space and time for ship movement, but at the same time we're still farming the good old way and getting enough food is a major topic. Priorities someone?Scaling down the level of advancement or just come up with another reason they wanted their planet, would have made it a lot better. But what they chose for this story is the equivalent of everyone having a smartphone in the dark ages.There is a reason the much more realistic The expanse was so popular, it's precisely this "realism" what made it great.Rebelmoon: To much emphasis on slowmotion, to much non human conversations (did chatgpt come up with this?), and why if we have super killer robots, are we still fighting next to them?If they would put in the same effort to the writing as they do into the cgi it could mount to something. Right now it's just a whole lot of mehhh, waste of time.

title: Fun rehash of sci fi genres
text: Take Star Wars, Gladiator, Warhammer, Mad Max, John Carter and a touch of a hundred westerns and you get this movie. Nothing new at all but it was still fun.My main gripe is the editing, it skips far too quickly from trope to trope which robs it of any depth, each character introduced has little to no motivation to join the main protagonists beyond being a cool addition to the gang.Perhaps the other movies dig further, perhaps there's a 37.63 hour Snyder cut, perhaps I don't care too much cos the movie was just a bit of dumb fun.Looking forward to next movie in the series and I'm sure I'll watch this one again soon.

title: Rebel Moon - Part One: A Child of Fire (2023)
text:
Kora (Sofia Boutella) is a former soldier who has adhered to a new life with a community of peaceful villagers. When their tranquility is threatened by the most ruthless military regime in the galaxy, the Motherworld. Kora rallies warriors from other planets and starts her own revolution in this space opera co-written, directed and produced by Zack Snyder.Zack Snyder has openly stated this franchise will be his version of "Star Wars" and I believe it does have potential for growth as there are ambitious creative decisions behind the screenplay such as the world-building and the established lore which I would have loved to see fleshed out. The universe has started out on the wrong footing due to the storyline feeling very derivative and the overlong runtime that does not justify the thinly veiled narrative surrounding revenge. The CGI and VFX are top-notch for a Netflix production as we are exposed to various new planets, with insight on the intricate character designs of the creatures that populate them. But this universe rings hollow due to all of the characters being under-developed and their motivations feeling contrived. This is why it does not seem like an organic transition when the rebels form a camaraderie. Their chemistry is nonexistent. Not to mention, many of the cast members deliver wooden performances which only concludes that the direction was not as sharp. The redeeming qualities lie in the cinematography which can be visually enchanting in certain scenes and the action sequences that are minimal yet remain engrossing including the slow-motion shots.One can hope that the issues mentioned will be
improved upon in the sequel. Slated to release next year. But I will be keeping my expectations at a minimum.IG: thecinephilereviews.

title: The worst movie ever
text: Plot is written by a 5 year old literally and that's not a figure of speech. Characters keep popping out of nowhere agreeing to a rebellion with no reason and the acting is beyond bad. It's like I have zero money for actors but I have money for cgi. What should I do? And the cgi is not that great either. While you're at it through a bunch of lens flare in it and it would look cool. I think someone at Netflix gave full creative control you Zack and now we see the results. Like a movie from a has been not a movie from a great director. Even though someone could argue that Zack was never great to start with.

title: And
text: A half. I haven't watched a movie in forever ( I watch all series now) but ran out of things and hadn't watched anything n Netflix in around 4 months. So instead of canceling my membership I decided to try this from the meager pickings. I thought it was decent. I feel movies unlike series are half complete/ unfulfilling. This wasn't bad for an action film tho it feels like a video game throughout a lot. Thr characters are ok. Kora leaves little to be desired beyond her action parts. I somehow missed Hopkins? I am looking forward to seeing what Atticus is so will watch the second part but by then i could be disinterested? Edit to add! I also cannot believe there is already over 1k reviews!

title: Embarassingly amateurish
text: "Rebel Moon" presents itself as a promising sci-fi epic, yet it stumbles significantly in its execution. The most glaring issue lies in its storytelling, which feels amateurish and lacks the depth and nuance necessary to truly captivate.Equally problematic is the shot sequencing and editing. It's evident that the team behind these aspects had a limited understanding of the craft. Instead of bringing a fresh perspective or innovative approach, the film resorts to standard tropes. However, these tropes are employed without a clear understanding of their underlying mechanics behind what works and what doesn't, leading to see the team behind the film as newcomers and out of place for a production of this scale.On a positive note, the CGI work in "Rebel Moon" is commendable. The visual effects are one of the few aspects where the film manages to meet expectations, providing some respite in an otherwise underwhelming production.

title: Actually pretty good....
text: This movie is a little long, there are some weaknesses in the script, and is somewhat uneven. That being said, I think it had some strong actors, a decent story that got stretched more than it should have, and an ending that did not work for me. The CGI was fairly good overall. A problem with the story was that they borrowed a bit much from other Sci fi movies. Not enough to be destructive for this movie, but Sci fi fans will recognize the borrowed pieces. There were some good actors who could have done more with an overall stronger story, but the acting was ok enough to keep me engaged. At the end of the movie, they let us know there will be a Part Two coming next April. I am hopeful it will be as good or better than Part One.

title: High production, terrible writing
text: I guess netflix wanted it's own space odyssey "star wars" saga, and went about writing it in a way that was so formulaic and tired as to render it boring. The characters were shallow, especially the evil ones, and the story totally predictable. Even George Lucas realized back in the 1970s that you can't make a character purely and sadisticly evil for no good reason, and here we are almost 50 years later as if those lessons had never been learned. The writing was like a souless corporate paint-by-numbers attempt at producing an "epic" story, and they failed misserably. Imagine the quality of the formulaic writing in all the Disney-produced Star Wars films, but much, much worse. I felt totally let down after all the hype.

title: Enough for me to continue the journey
text: Rebel moon part one is really solid & enough for me to continue the journey most critics or bad reviews are comparing this to legendary star wars whilebit might look similar or under the same genera but it differently made and remember it's a huge world building and most of the characters need more times which is coming in Zack Snyder cut and part two the story given to us is a bit of each and every other characters making Kora the centre of it .Visually it's a piece of arts every Frame is breathtaking the chemistry between the cast and changing lines of dialogue is good a very solid 8/10 looking forward for part two.

title: It was good, but...
text: One of my criteria for rating a movie is based on how I feel about my time after it's over. Did I regret the time taken to watch it? No, so that was a plus. Were the actors compelling & believable? Some were. Some weren't. Were the special and visual effects believable? Again, some were and some missed the mark completely. It's as if the effects were done two completely different ways so it half worked. Was the storyline unique, solid and/or told well? I split that down the middle as well. The storyline itself reminded me of several other movies that were done better such as The Magnificent Seven (old & newer versions), Star Wars, and another that slips my mind right now. So it wasn't unique. I also got the feeling that some of the story got left on the editing room floor because there were a few "huh?" moments. Was it predictable? Parts were; some were not. So that left me with a rating near the middle. I gave it a 6 because at the end, I did want to see where part 2 will go. So it's a good flick but not a great one.

title: IMHO: It feels uninspired.
text: I am not a filmmaker, so before I write this review, I will explain this is purely my own opinion. I am not in any way a fan of Mr. Snyder's work. I do have my favorites; I still like Man of Steel. 300 was a visual masterpiece at that time. The stories themselves, to me, are lacking.But I was interested in watching Rebel Moon. The promise that it was Mr. Snyder's vision of what he could do in a Star Wars-esque setting sounded intriguing.I read in many reviews, also from critics whose opinions I value, that the movie borrowed a lot from movies like Star Wars. I don't think that is a bad thing. It is not that SW has to sole proprietary on an epic space opera. Put Ben Hurr, Spartacus, and Gladiator next to each other. Good movies are allowed to have their work to be the inspiration of other work.My issue with Rebel Moon is that it feels uninspired. I certainly believe that Mr. Snyder has been brooding on the story and world-building for decades. And that is what I miss. It doesn't show.It doesn't feel like this has been the passion project from someone who wanted to tell an epic story because - to be fair - this is a very basic story that lacks the grandiose. It feels more like this story was told through concept art, and it never got a chance to be told in words.Visually, it is "not bad". You could even call it great at moments. But it feels 'upscaled'. Watching it on 4K, I never felt I got a sharp image. It felt too blurry. But still, it has good visual moments. Some smart design choices here and there. But it still feels like I have been reading through the book 'The Art Of Rebel Moon. ' Which, I suppose, might be really good.But here is where I think a lot of filmmakers think that it is easy to create a world and a story like Star Wars. To be fair, it, too, is not a deep story. But what it had was excellent characters who you cared for. Building upon great characters was a pretty thin story, but it didn't matter; you wanted to spend time with your 'friends' to have a good time.Rebel Moon lacks this connection. The back stories of the characters feel flimsy, and there is no real connection to the viewer. There is no one you can identify yourself to. This makes you a spectator who is not influenced by what you see on the screen.It doesn't help that the dialogue is mediocre. There are no great, passionate conversations. No expression of emotion that is heartfelt. The pace of the conversations is edited to make it feel like every character is waiting for the other one to finish their sentence properly.Where most people and critics claim the film to be a copy of Star Wars, I actually think it is not that bad, even if they do sometimes refer to the 'bad power' as 'the empire.' Not smart. I actually see much more of a direct link to the game Mass Effect 2. The story is very similar: Outer world human colonies are threatened by a massive power, and you, as the protagonist, are being told to build up a team of misfits across the galaxy to stand a chance against the impending danger.As I referred to earlier, the difference is that in Mass Effect 2, the characters are so well-written and likable that the same flimsy story is just the glue to get you to unique places and situations.I did finish the movie simply because I wanted to see it through to the end and write a review while watching it in its entirety. Besides all the other things I described here, the only thing I really disliked was the slow motions. This is hugely understated in other reviews. This might have worked in Mr. Snyder's earlier movies when this was still a novel idea. But we have seen good action scenes before, and there often was no reason to pay attention to this. Other reviewers have described it as, and I agree, the action being paused. It takes away any feeling of urgency and totally takes you out of the pace of the combat. If all the slow-motion had been taken out of the movie, we would have been given 15 minutes back - and I honestly think I am not kidding.My word of advice to Mr. Snyder is (but who am I to claim he should listen to me): If you are given $115m to bring your movie to life, do research. Don't squander that money with the idea that you know best. If you think you have a great story, get the best writers to take your good story and make it amazing. When you are the director, listen to feedback from your editors and directors of photography, and use all their skills to make a good movie. It feels like the story was amazing in your head, but it did not translate like that to the viewers.I hope that part two will redeem itself in April 2024, but at this moment, it will feel like a chore to review it. And that is different from how you want people to start watching your movie.

title: 9/10 technical score, 3/10 artistic merit
text: Rebel Moon, Child of Fire - From the director of so many personal favourites of mine, this is the second of Zack Snyder's Netflix made films following his 3 gold standard superhero films after which he was removed from the helm of Warner Bros' superhero universe midstream in a Hollywood power play drama that is worth its own movie. Essentially a Star Wars movie pitch he made that he then repurposed into its own saga, this movie, like the original Star Wars, mashes together numerous genres, influences and imaginative ideas around some stunning action scenes and a solid soundtrack. A young woman living a simple farmer's life on a nowhere important world is caught up in a galactic war when the empire enslaves her village, forcing her to seek allies to protect it. Essentially Star Wars meets the Magnificent Seven.Sadly, this film lacks the charm, earnest performances and basic "wow" that propelled not only Star Wars but most of Snyder's previous movies to greatness. There's nothing obviously wrong with what anyone's doing, and the set pieces, action scenes and cinematography are all technically excellent, but it doesn't all come together to get you invested in the characters or their story. The main characters are more C list than the supporting characters like Djimon Hounsou and Charlie Hunan and seem to be going through the motions, while Sir Anthony Hopkins is wasted briefly voicing a droid with performance issues. He may have thought he was playing a Transformer after appearing in one of those movies. The assembled heroes are given little development and have little chemistry in the brief time they are all together, while the story doesn't unite the influences it taps. And the villain is no Darth Vader. It's clear that pieces are being assembled for the sequel due to arrive next year so it doesn't stand on its own as a complete story like the first part of most trilogies do. If the conclusion answers some of these issues then this first chapter's impression may be revised higher but for now It's like the poor Star Wars sequels for adults, of which George Lucas said "They're well-made (but) There's nothing new."Snyder's landmark films were all adaptations of seminal comic book tales (300, Watchmen) or screenplays written by noted writers like David Goyer (who wrote the Nolan Dark Knigjt trilogy) and Chris Terrio (Oscar winning Argo). This one however was written by Snyder as was his previous low scoring movie Sucker Punch. It seems that the magic formula is for Snyder to continue to add his signature polish to someone else's script and bring their characters to life. Which is all the more reason for Netflix to buy the rights to finish the Justice League saga from bankrupt Warner Bros and get the squad back together.

title: Reinterpretation of "7 Samurai" by visionary Zack Snyder
text: The reworking of the film "7 Samurai" by the talented director Zack Snyder causes me some doubt. Undoubtedly, he is a master of visual design and creating intense action scenes, and also skillfully conveys emotional depth. However, I liked only two of his projects: the epic story "300 Spartans" (2006) about the battle of Thermopylae and the dark and gloomy film "Guardians" (2009).The director invariably follows his style, and we never cease to rejoice in a pleasant composition with a bright palette, interesting characters and colorful conflicts. However, sometimes his visual solutions are just annoying and tiring to the eye.Formally, the film aims to become an action adventure with elements of a space western and the Japanese cinematographic style of "tumbara" in a fantastic medieval neo-futurist entourage of a space opera.In general, this is a pleasant entertaining movie, in which there are many exaggerations and exaggerated emotions. From a visual point of view, it is not inferior to "Star Wars", and in the semantic aspect, perhaps even surpasses them. However, for me it is just a beautiful cosmic fairy tale with bright and strong female characters. The women in this series get a huge space to reveal their strength and fill them with muscular images. It seems to me that this is the highest point of matriarchal visual perfection, which can only be compared with the dazzling beauty of women. This is something like the Trinity visual syndrome, which makes you fall in love with the bright dreams of a Crocus immersed in sadness.Among the male characters, three roles can be distinguished - Ed Skrein, Charlie Hunnam and the Irishman Fra Fee. The rest of the male roles are a dim shadow in this starburst of "Snyder's vision."I must admit, I hardly watched this movie. Perhaps it is aimed at a teenage audience, and throughout the entire viewing I watched it embarrassingly, but with respect for the master. However, it's not for nothing that the finale of the picture turned out to be the most interesting and fascinating, it deftly holds attention and arouses curiosity. This is a very skillful, addictive ending.The plot of the film is too fabulous, and some scenes are greatly exaggerated. The acrobatics of the main character leaves much to be desired, but we must pay tribute to Zack Snyder - as always, it looks beautiful!

title: Wondering if this was written by chat GPT?
text:
I'm wondering if Chat gpt wrote this off a brief to make it sort of like a Star Wars story, include some Vikings, a Lara Croft type female lead, South African baddies, Black Panther, Tarzan, Chinese action movie heroine and Sons of Anarchy (if it was in Northern Ireland and just to stack the movie with some totty!), then add in an evil general with great cheekbones modelled on the worst of 3rd reich.Mental concept! Which is why this movie
really didn't seem to go anywhere most of the time while they rode across space collecting various odds and sods only to end up with a final battle straight out of a gaming programme and some cheesy dialogue.So yeah, that's pretty much it.

title: I'm glad this came out on Netflix and not the theatres
text: Overall, I liked the movie, but this is also the kind of movie that you have to watch with your expectations in check. I thought the movie was entertaining because it felt like I was playing a video game for two hoursI liked the visuals and I like his ability to create action scenes. Some of it can seem over the top, but I still generally like itI thought the world-building was very weak and the world itself seemed non-sensical. The movie starts us off in a medieval Scandinavian-type but on a moon of a ringed planet. There's a war going on between rebels and evil empire. Somehow this village-which is miles away from a space port and who farms the land with horses-produces enough food to attract the attention of the rebels and the evil empire, and thus our hero gets her call to action. She must gather a crew of warriors to save this villageThe characters that we get introduced to are very shallow and not much is given to their character development. The story follows it's beats and is very simpleIf you like the genre and already have a Netflix account then it's worth watching. It's not worth opening a new Netflix account for nor is it worth seeing in the theaters.

title: Slowmo does not cover up bad story telling
text: Hmm where to start? It's not the worst film, but it's not good either. It's watchable. Feels like it was wrote by AI; if I'm honest.And the character building is rushed.Charlie Hunnams northern Irish accent it's the worst but it's not much better than Brad Pitt in The Devils OwnI think I'm just longing for a good Sci-fi, the last good one Blade Runner 2049 or Dune in my opinion.But this is neither - it's pretty obvious where it's going. The narration/flash backs and "world building" is painful at points as was when they bounce from planet to planet to pick up different "avengers" for their "suicide squad"Was good to see Djimon Hounsou however, I think that guy is a good actor.

title: Excitement lasted 3 minutes and 8 seconds.
text:
I'm having trouble even starting to write something good about this movie so instead here's a play by play recap.*three minutes in*
"Why is she doing that? Why am I already annoyed?"*Five minutes in*
"okay that was a waste of 5 minutes with random and irrelevant information, but alright, gotta start somewhere."*Nine minutes in and another 4 minutes of irrelevant cringe and bad acting, some plot arrived.*
"YES!, finally something interesti..."*12 seconds later*
"BORED, SO BORED"*13 minutes of random discussion about farming later*
"I CAN DO THIS! I CAN SURVIVE TILL SOMETHING HAPPENS"*7 minutes of more nothing happening and absolutely random content*
"Aight, I'm out"My dream was to have an adult version of something in the Star Wars universe and when I heard this was coming, even though it was rewritten to be something else, I was as excited as any person who grew up on it, expecting some good sci-fi.Twenty seven excruciating minutes later, I understood why even Disney didn't want to touch this, and that's saying something considering 99% of what they released was garbage.

title: A visual spectacle
text: Zack Snyder has described this movie as the Seven Samurai in space, and this movie proudly shows its influences on its sleeves. Like Lucas before him, Snyder borrows ideas and imagery from the classics of his day, from the magnificent seven to Excalibur and of course, Star Wars, but all done in his own signature bombastic style.The visuals and action scenes are as usual immaculate, and the universe Zack has created looks amazing, with a price tag of 80 million it still manages to look better than movies with three times the budget.The big flaw is that you can tell the movie was cut down for a shorter run time. The hour or so cut content would explore the characters more deeply and elaborate on their stories.Still, the story that did survive is great and serves to whet your appetite and pique your interest. Can't wait for part 2.

title: Stop Giving Zack Snyder So Many Chances
text: I will preface this review by saying that I am a huge fan of any type of sci-fi or fantasy world building. I know that it is extremely difficult and takes a lot of imagination to create a world and bring it to fruition in any sort of medium.With that being said, this was simply a bad movie. The characters were bland and underdeveloped, the plot was paper-thin, and the movie was heavily-reliant upon many slow motion action sequences. There were many times at this movie that I laughed out loud at the absurdity of some of the slow-motion shots.I think we need to take a step back and ask why Zack Snyder has been continually given all of these large budgets to make his "visions", which all turn out to be versions of CGI-reliant, slow-motion plotless "epics". When 300 came out and that technology was someone new everyone loved it, but here we are almost 20 years later and he is still playing his "greatest hit" to the tune of a $90 million budget.

title: Not Perfect, but Entertaining
text: I am conflicted on my rating. Acting is probably a 2/10 and Zack Snyder's use of blurry visuals throughout scenes and the screen edges is a 1/10 (just like in The Army of the Dead, although RM was a tiny bit better.) As far as the story is concerned, it's a simple one, not confusing at all.....a few people from a village under siege go searching for fighters to help them....so easy 9/10 for the story....nothing complicated. The fight scenes are a 9/10. Those are done right! Yes, there are the typical Snyder slow motion scenes, but he didn't go too overboard this time around (he didn't pull a full Michael Bay if you know what I mean!) Some of the CGI was a little off, but not bad....7/10. I went into this movie with a low expectation given all the bad reviews and hate surrounding it, but honestly, it wasn't that bad of a movie. It was entertaining, not too much fluff between the action, and again, the action scenes were pretty good. I get that it's getting flake for being more of a stylish movie.....quantity over quality.....but it's still entertaining and the lead actress, although not the best actress, is very good in action movies. Is it worth a try....yes.... I say so. Maybe one and done, but worth a try.

title: Who are these people?
text: A decent script, in the hands of a decent cast, will give viewers' insight into characters' motivations. Rebel Moon lacks this. Instead, we have an ensemble of shallowness, with interactions that either laboriously describe some aspect of the story, or that simply tick off a few stock character traits. We are left with mannequins, and it's a shame. Just the lightest smattering of heartfelt moments between some of the characters would have helped. For example, the protagonist saves a young woman from an unpleasant situation. Foreshadowing this by showing the two of them sharing a friendly moment would have helped lift what was otherwise a set-piece action scene. What we have is a souless rendering of tick box sci-fi, people, conflict, environment, but no characterisation.It's a shame. The special effects are great. The story as a whole is reminiscent of the Seven Samurai inspired Magnificent Seven, and offers a creative interpretation of it. It is well-made, and the universe is believable, in as far that Star Wars is believable.Its factory made sci-fi. If you crave laser pistols at high-noon, give it a go. If you are looking for fully conceived characters, try elsewhere.

title: In a world that loves slow motion
text: I actually started off enjoying the film then I realised that every couple of minutes they decided to use a slow motion effect and I don't mean for any major plot points or scenes that drive the story, a dog jumping over a tree, put it in slow motion, putting on a robe/cape - put it in slow motion.. it got used so much that the film just started to annoy me more than me enjoying it. Such a shame as if it wasn't for all the pointless matrix style effects I would have been able to get through this. I really did try to like and watch all of the film but I couldn't. I'm on my christmas holidays and shouting at the TV is not how I'm going to start it. Very nice looking film, the bonus is you'll get to appreciate it so much more as its in slow motion. Also a very strange blur affect is used around the edge of the screen on certain scenes, there is a robot sitting down talking to a girl, the legs are blurry and the edge of the shot but not the center of it. Had high hopes but I'm now going to go and watch rogue one to remind me of what a great Sci fi film can be.

title: "Rebel Moon Part 1" unfolds in a world teetering on the edge of rebellion. The story introduces us to a protagonist, Alex Mercer, a seemingly ordinary individual thrust into e
text: "Rebel Moon Part 1" unfolds in a world teetering on the edge of rebellion. The story introduces us to a protagonist, Alex Mercer, a seemingly ordinary individual thrust into extraordinary circumstances. As the narrative kicks off, we witness Alex navigating a society dominated by a tyrannical regime, where dissent is suppressed, and freedom is a distant memory.The opening scenes establish the oppressive atmosphere, with sweeping shots of a dystopian landscape. The government's iron grip is palpable, and the citizens live in fear. Alex, initially an apolitical character, inadvertently becomes a symbol of resistance when a chance encounter reveals a dark secret that could change the course of the entire society.The pacing in "Rebel Moon Part 1" is a rollercoaster, with tension escalating as Alex grapples with newfound responsibilities. The character development is gradual, allowing viewers to connect with Alex as they witness their transformation from an average individual to a reluctant hero. The relatable nature of the protagonist adds depth to the story, making it accessible to a broad audience.The plot unfolds through a series of twists and turns, keeping the audience on the edge of their seats. As Alex allies with a diverse group of rebels, each member brings unique skills and perspectives to the table. The ensemble cast adds layers to the narrative, creating a dynamic group that faces challenges together, fostering camaraderie that resonates with viewers.The world-building in "Rebel Moon Part 1" is commendable. The filmmakers invest time in creating a believable universe with its own history, politics, and societal norms. The attention to detail enhances the viewing experience, immersing the audience in a fully realized and engaging setting.Visually, the film boasts stunning cinematography, capturing the stark contrast between the opulence of the ruling class and the squalor of the oppressed. The use of color and lighting contributes to the overall atmosphere, effectively conveying the emotions associated with each scene. The action sequences are choreographed with precision, delivering intense and memorable moments that leave a lasting impact.While "Rebel Moon Part 1" follows a familiar hero's journey, it injects freshness into the formula by exploring themes of sacrifice, unity, and the resilience of the human spirit. The screenplay balances character-driven moments with high-stakes action, ensuring that the story resonates on both emotional and visceral levels.As the first installment concludes, "Rebel Moon Part 1" leaves audiences craving more. The climax sets the stage for a larger conflict, promising an epic continuation in future installments. The average storyline is elevated by stellar performances, compelling characters, and a world that invites viewers to invest in the unfolding saga.In essence, "Rebel Moon Part 1" may adhere to some conventions of the genre, but it distinguishes itself through its execution. The film successfully captures the essence of rebellion, making it a thrilling ride that captivates audiences and sets the stage for an eagerly anticipated sequel.

title: The level of disappointment is unmatched
text: Considering the cast, budget, director, production house and story available for this film, I have to say, this may very well be the overwhelming winner of biggest flop in cinematic history.I'm genuinely frustrated I wasted over 2 hours of my life watching this high school film class final project after having it be promoted as one of the best Netflix releases coming up all year long.The most irritating part is hearing the hearsay that the "Snyder Cut" R rated version is basically a different movie and significantly better. Why is Netflix commissioning a producer to make a multi part movie that are multiple hours each, then completely changing the directors vision. They may as well hire a 10 year old to make the movie and edit it the way they want, rather than hiring a phenomenal director and butchering his work to oblivion.If Netflix thought they were making their own version of Dune, I cannot express enough, how they made the exact opposite of it in every single way shape and form. If Netflix thought they had in house and subscriber issues before, I guarantee this is going to magnify those concerns exponentially, and rightfully so.

title: A Visually Stunning but Hollow Sci-Fi Epic
text: Rebel Moon is a visually stunning film. The CGI is well done, and the cinematography is impressive. However, that's the only positive thing I can say about it.I'm a fan of Zack Snyder, but he has some serious flaws as a filmmaker. This film suffers from a lack of character development and plot. For about 90 minutes, the film is just a series of scenes where the main characters travel from planet to planet, recruiting allies for their cause. These scenes are somewhat unnecessary and boring, and they don't advance the story or the characters. Such as the one with the flying creature. What was the purpose of that scene?Some scenes are also disturbing and offensive, like the one with the gay bar and the sexual assault or the grape scene. What was the purpose of these scenes? How did they contribute to the film?The main problem with this film is the lack of plot. It doesn't feel like a movie, but rather a collection of random events. The film showed more scenes than needed and less than required.

title: Just bad
text: I really wanted to enjoy this movie but i ended up watching only a half o it and i was bored as hell. I expected this movie to be a wonder for the eyes but the is very dark, out of focus camera, bad cgi (i'd watch Independence Day any day over this crap) and terrible action scenes.The slow motion scenes don't make any sense to me and don't bring any joy for the human eye.The characters are also bleak and uninteresting as well, you have the bleak main character with the typical tragic backstory, the unworthy merchant, the swordswoman, the disgraced general, etc. Nothing fresh in here, all the typical character you would see in most movies.Let's not forget the "bad b***h" moments in this movie, i mean the typical Holywood crap where a 50kg lady easily beats 10 trained soldiers. I get it she was very well trained but damn it look weird every time i see it.Overall. It's just a bad movie and boy i wanted to be good and enjoy this one.

title: An Enjoyable Film
text: I read somewhere (who knows if this is accurate) that this was initially developed as a Star Wars spinoff.
